comments.text:
Going for mass sales of units at a cheaper price instead of fewer sales of units at a more expensive price is how AMD can make significant gains in Nvidia's dominant market share.

If AMD just try to match Nvidia with pricing and specs, they will squander their opportunity. They need to undercut Nvidia and go for profit through the mass sale of units to gamers who are pretty desperate for better value for money than Nvidia are offering.

If the RX9070 XT is very close in performance to the RTX 5080 at around 600-650 dollars, that would pretty much blow Nvidia out of the water.

The FSR 4 vs DLSS 4 software battle may also be a factor for those gamers who are not AMD or Nvidia fan boys, but probably not as much as the value for money for the raw power of the silicon being offered by these two companies.
comments.author: @Cristorbius

Then and only then will AMD gain any marketshare from Nvidia. And even then, AMD would get maybe 2% more marketshare.

Nvidia wins again!
Nvidia always wins!

comments.text:
Jay, you thought $650 would be an aggressive, "cover costs" price for the RX 9070 XT? Just goes to show how effective Nvidia's pricing strategy has been on even hardware reviewer perceptions...

I bet AMD could have gone as low as $500 to "cover costs" on the XT. And I think they chose to go lower on the XT than they originally planned but attempt to keep the non-XT on the higher side.

I'm thinking the yields are probably similar in both SKUs, so they opted to take a slightly larger hit in margin on the higher end SKU with hopes that the higher margin on the lower SKU will overall balance out their final gross margin.

I think, ultimately they priced the SKUs too close together, in a sane market, but since we are in an insane market where everything sells... they may have made the best business decision.

comments.text:
Lost opportunity... The 9070xt should've gone 549 and just cut NVidia at the knees with the 9070 vanilla at 449 to basically head off any potential of a 5060ti. That cyberpunk ray tracing number tells us that these cards follow suit with the prior generations in terms of ray tracing once we get into heavy effects. It's an improvement, but I have a feeling it isn't going to be enough when a cherry picked number is over 20% behind the competition. With the 5070 vanilla expected to be about 20% behind the 5070ti, well, that might be a problem. I'd be curious how the black myth wukong numbers look with ray tracing maxed out.

If we've learned anything from last gen, it's just being a bit cheaper and better at raster isn't enough. If it was, they'd be higher than 10% market share. 

I had hoped this would be the round that AMD manages to make NVidia rethink their midrange presence, but it appears that won't be the case.

comments.text: @jayztwocents  Hi, I'm an Italian fan of yours and I have a request for you. I've been using both Amd and Nvidia GPUs for years and I've tried every kind of custom on the market. One thing that has never changed, unfortunately, is the approach of manufacturers to thermal pad management. Especially in the latest generations, custom graphics use thermal pads of different sizes that are not always easily found on the market or at astronomical prices. I think you are one of the most authoritative voices and it would be nice if, with some other authoritative colleague, you made an appeal to the various distributors to provide specific thermal pad kits for the video cards sold. Thermal putty solutions are very dirty and above all we really don't know what we have in our hands since we often order from any site... Thanks if you accept this invitation.

comments.text:
I like the pricing.  Won't be getting it though as this 4080 FE will do me for another generation.  The whole pricing though looking at Nvidia is just ugh.  It's like they're wanting to get out of the gamer consumer market but they're slowly pulling a plaster/bandaid off a very hairy arm and going small tug, ow, small tug than just ripping it off completely and leaving the gaming market for AMD and Intel...

Which might actually be a good thing, maybe..  Might reset things, get rid of fake frame insertion, get power levels back down again and bring things back to native generation.  But software aka game developers need to do that anyways due to poor optimisation in some titles these days.

Honestly, I wouldn't care if Nvidia did leave this particular market.  They clearly want to.  As for the card shortages, most of the ordered stuff is probably for their AI server gpu's and they didn't see this market as important.

AMD should go for the throat, glad they decided to do so.  Would've had more of a impact if there were AMD made cards as I can't see AIB's keeping close to RRP which will lessen the plan to gain market share.

I think at this point a large segment of the gaming population is frankly just ready for any excuse to stick it to Nvidia, after they've been sticking it to us for so long.
I'm not a big gamer, but need to support three high-resolution monitors, and I was running an AMD Radeon R9 390X from about 2015 until about a year ago, when I was given an Nvidia RTX 2060 (the R9 390X only supported my Dell U4021QW 5120x2160 central monitor at 4K, so I had black spaces on the sides, which was unsightly) .
I've been looking at new video cards 'just because', but the 50-series from Nvidia were such a disappointment, and I wasn't sure what to do.
Now the 9070 XT is giving me hope that I might be able to get a new video card for only around $600.00, and not support Nvidia, or buy used, which would be wonderful.

comments.text: AMD is making a 7800xt profit on the 9070xt.  The last $117 of the price is going to TSMC, power connectors, retailers and AIBs.  I hope the 7800xt does not have margins too slim. The 9070xt price is UNBELIEVABLE.  I put the number into a VLSI chip calculator and found that @ 70% yields the 9070xt chip costs $80 more to make, plus $20 for 20% extra power, and $17 for AIB/Retailer markups = $117 more cost to make vs. 7800xt.  So on the last $120 of price on a 9070xt, AMD clears $3 ONLY ...

comments.text: I was always an AMD guy. From a Radeon 6850, to an RX 480 to a 5700XT. I thought NVIDIA users were paying more for less. At least in numbers that was what it looked like. But boy I was wrong. I finally gave it a chance and tried NVIDIA for the first time. I got myself a 4070 and for the first time ever I had a really good gaming experience. No more hiccups, no more fiddling around with settings trying to make things smooth. I don't know what it is. If it's drivers, developers integration, NVIDIA ecosystem, gsync, dlss or what. But I finally got a good, smooth, hassle free gaming experience. I'm never going back to AMD. I learnt my lesson. No matter what raw numbers say. No matter what reviews say. There's something more that only with experience and daily use you can appreciate. If you are a hardcore AMD user as I was and you are reading this try it by yourself. Give NVIDIA a chance, you'll thank me later

comments.text:
"How much do you think we can sell it for", basically translates to "how greedy can we be and still look good". 

A dollar more than it's worth, is still taking a dollar more than you deserve, thus it's literally only "how greedy can we be".

On the opposite side, it's selling at a loss, thus practically charity, and no business can survive that unless they're taking donations.

I'd say take the total cost of manufacturing, plus the minimum profit needed to maintain the business, and price accordingly, 5%.  If +5%, you can maintain profit with 10% discounts, allowing some flexibility without taking losses.  Worse cause scenario, you can clear out the stock with minimum pricing at the manufacturing cost, breaking even, and recuperating the funds to reinvest in better opportunities.

comments.text:
I've always preferred ATi (AMD). When I mean always, I mean since 3Dfx went out of business. I started with a Radeon 64MB ViVo and haven't stopped since. I prefer the AMD Driver software. I prefer the layout as well as the look. I prefer the power consumption being lower. I could buy nVIDIA, and I have many of their cards in my collection, but I just don't like the 12v high power connector. I also don't like how they overclock their silicon from the factory to such an insane degree that the power usage is out of control. I don't like the way nVIDIA didn't add power circuitry to load balance the power load across all lines on the 12vHPWR connector.

And then there's nVIDIA's pricing, issues with missing rOPs, cards catching fire, etc.

I'm sticking with AMD once again. Probably the Power Color 9070XT Red Devil or the Sapphire RX 9070 XT Nitro+. The Red Devil has dual 8-pin so most likely that one.

comments.text: Let us appreciate the fact RDNA4 is an architectural improvement over RDNA3 even though on the same node technically. Unlike nvidia. So a 64 CU card(which in the RDNA3 generation is a 7800XT)9070 XT is just as fast as a 96 CU card(7900 XTX). So AMD gained at least 40% IPC on their RDNA architecture. With clock speed increases and IPC a theoretical 9090XTX with 96 cus would have sandwiched between an RTX 4090 and RTX 5090 in performance and if AMD made it and priced it at say $1199 people would buy it. Of course one would have to give it 32GB VRAM as well...a 512-bit memory interface.

comments.text: Forget MSRP, it just won't happen.  Expect at least 100 on top of MSRP - AT LEAST.  Also nobody talks about IMAGE QUALITY itself, there is a difference between AMD and Nvidia - and a big difference between FSR + DLSS when looking at image quality.  Also - Wattage/Temps/OC potential is also a factor.  An example is out of the box an Asus 5070ti OC can easily be ramped up to 5080 stock speeds for 300 less than the same brand card (5080) is worth.   I'd like to see the 9070XT match the 5070ti with the same ray tracing on, no DLSS, no FSR.  Then this card would be absolutely worth buying over an Nvidia option.  AMD genuinely make decent GPU cards nowadays, let alone their gaming cpus being absolutely awesome so I'm no Nvidia fanboy but to get me to switch to AMD I need more guarantees on quality over just cheaper prices.

comments.text: IMO seeing that spec sheet, it already shows me AMD fumbled this one too. AI is just not a better replacement for raw performance gains overall, and yet these cards have way more AI processing hardware rather than raw performance increasing hardware. People have already shown they don't really think much of adding a bit more to what they have to pay if they can get what seems to be the best or "better" performance instead of cheaping out via the next best thing. That's why Ngreedia is so far ahead right now. It doesn't help that AMD board partners seem to be using 12v-2x6 connectors for the 9070's as well, and we have zero information on whether or not these cards have wire current load balancing hardware in them (regardless if the wattage is 200~300 or so watts).

comments.text:
Excellent! In 3 years AMD will have the got to budget gamer GPU like they always do. I kid, but not really. Last month we sold both our PURE 7800xt and 7900GRE for exactly what we bought them new for. We were in hopes these would be under 700 each so we would invest very little after including. what we recouped on the 70 series GPUs. We win. 

 Even if the Sapphire version is a bit more than the 600, we still are under our budget. 

 I understand many people buy new every other or every 3 gens. Since Lockdown showed us how screwed up tech can get, we resell and upgrade every generation. We have not been failed yet starting with a 1080Ti- making the move to AMD6800xt, then up to the 7900GRE and now the 9070xt and not once did we lose money. Effectively my chain back to when the 1080TI cost me 700 new, I have not spent a single pence up til now.  The 50 here and there has balanced out and meant that original 700 has last me 8 years. 

 Do you upgrade/trade in every gen? Why or why not?

As for the 5070 ti, the real price is $850-900. Maybe as low as $800 if you get super lucky. Those aren't scalped prices, that's what the AIBs are setting their prices to. If there aren't any cards available at $750, and the AIB cards are all $150 more, then the actual price is that, not this imaginary number you can never actually buy the card at. So we're looking at a $250+ difference for basically the same performance.

The 50 Series, except for the 5090, are just utter dogshit anyway. Totally hardware-gimped, named multiple tiers above what they should be and stupidly overpriced. On top of that.


Melting connector issues


Black screening due to bad drivers


Missing ROPs, which can result in substantial performance reductions


Absolutely horrendous supply, which causes prices to skyrocket. This is seriously beyond a joke at this point, and I don't understand why idiots constantly keep forgiving Nvidia for this. It's one of the main reasons why they are able to get away with this shit.

Hopefully, AMD can gain a significant amount of market share with RDNA 4. Currently, Nvidia is the dominant player in the gaming GPU market, and it's negatively impacting gamers. Pure domination by one company in an industry is never a good thing for consumers. The more competition there is, the better it is for consumers. Competition forces and pressurizes companies to release better products at more aggressive prices. Competition is the key to a healthy industry, and it always benefits the consumer.

comments.text:
For in-depth technicalities I'm watching GamersNexus and der8auer videos. I watch Jayz$0.02 for the vibe check. And it's vibing good!!!

The pricing is almost best case scenario as far as I could realistically expect (I had hoped the XT would launch for as $550 and the non-XT for $450), though the non-XT only being $50 less than the XT is a rather stupid decision. I expect this to be the basic upsell strategy and that the non-XT will swiftly drop in price closer to $500 to reflect the performance gap between the two.

Performance slides look promising, though as always I'll wait for independent reviewers like GamersNexus, der8auer and HUB to run your tests and give your numbers to form my final opinion. But so far things are looking pretty juicy. Waiting for the reviews is going to be tough!

Now they just need to be actually available and in great enough numbers that the actual market price for these GPUs won't get inflated through scarcity surcharges or snatched up by scalpers (at least here AMD's lesser popularity can be a boon as scalpers may be far less interested in these than the Nvidia GPUs). I am definately interested in this. If I can get a good partner model 9070 XT (something like a Sapphire Nitro, Powercolour Red Devil or an XFX Mercury) for not too much over 750 here in Germany (that would include VAT of course), I'm sold. This would be a huge upgrade over my ageing GTX 1080!

Come on AMD, at this point you can barely screw this up as long as you got a solid launch inventory!

comments.text: I am not sure people understand what is going on, no matter how well received these cards is there is no way for AMD to take more market share. The worlds silicon wafer production capacity is at maximum, every year companies like AMD have to negotiate with TSMC and prepay for their production, right now they are 10% of the graphics market if they wanted to be 15% they would have to sign up for more production, but they can't because their isn't any A.I is taking 80% of NVIDIA's production. The only thing that could happen is AMD gets some goodwill from this and quickly sells out of what they have. They don't have the volume to deliver millions of extra video cards and steal market from NVIDIA it is just not possible with what is going on today with wafer manufacturing.

comments.text: It depends. 9070's are the same GPU's but with a small defect, so it still works as a 9070, whereas the full chip is in the XT. The production cost at tsmc is exactly the same for a fully functional chip or a broken one. You pay per wafer, and you absorb the loss of faulty chips, not tsmc. That means AMD wants to sell these faulty chips at a lower price (instead of throwing them in the garbage), but the price cannot be SO low that everyone wants the lower spec card instead of the fully functional GPU. If the non-XT is priced close to the XT, that could mean that yields are high, and that AMD would prefer that you buy the XT?

comments.text:
The problem I have with the $600 MSRP for the RX 9070 XT is the concept of "profitting" on the next generation.  AMD needs to do more than just make sales but also deliver on customer support to secure whatever ground they gain.  But for next gen, the "70 class" needs to sufficiently beat the RX 9070 series with an acceptable price.  Jacking up the price $200 to $300 next gen for its "7" tier is not going to help even if Nvidia sets the price of the RTX 6070 to $900 and both have similar uplifts.

Meanwhile, I do agree that AMD needs to decouple their naming from Nvidia's, but the similarity for the RX 9000 series is because AMD is trying to sell to Nvidia fanboys who feel betrayed.  AMD wants to enlist the potential defectors, and they need to write the propaganda in a language they understand.  Honestly, I want the entire naming scheme overhauled.  We can reserve the 0 tier for naming the GPU family, but make use of the 1, 2, 3, and 4 tiers.  The 1 tier should be "integrated GPU replacement" tier.  Anything lower belongs to a different naming class as they are just extra display outputs.  Then the 2 tier goes to budget gaming GPUs.  3 tier has low end GPUs, 4 tier for mid grade, 5 tier for upper mid.  Marketting needs to do some decoupling from using the symbolism of 9 as the top tier.  Drop the top end to like tier 7, opening up 8 and 9 as a symbol of growth for later generations.  I don't believe it will be bad if naming schemes use hexidecimal.

@JDubST 1.  Alienware 27 4K Dual-Resolution Gaming Monitor - AW2725QF 180Hz is $499.99 as of today.

GPU manufacturers need to get ahead of the curve and catch up to the rest of the gaming industry with on-par pricing.

comments.text: And it's not 300W over 16 wires.  Half of them are ground and don't deliver current.  That leaves 8 wires actually carrying usable current. But wait, a lot of PSUs don't have true 8-pin connectors.  You get one 8 and one 6-pin with a 2-pin sidecar that just reuses a couple wires.  So 16 becomes 8 and of those 8, only 7 are carrying usable power.  Works out to 43 watts per yellow wire

Not going to bore you with a personal horror story, but electrical fires are my greatest fear and the anxiety of the thought of it happening has put me in the habit of unplugging anything that isn't a massive kitchen appliance when I am done using it for the last 20 years. Yeah I unplug my washer and dryer too.

@-3 Sapphire actually put a fuse in the card, so it will blow before the connector melts. Also it's a 300W card using a connector that's supposed to handle 600W. I wouldn't be worried. comments.text: @RatedMforMatt-ure You know what I actually get where youre coming from now that you explain it. I sold my ps5 like a year ago and I was going to play my ps4 until they basically stopped supporting it and quit gaming entirely because Im fed up with the gaming industry for much of the same reasons you are with Nvidia. I want to get into sim racing though so I decided to build a pc. I have been shopping for GPUs since October and I got into researching on GPUs and was aware of the Nvidia hate. My friend who put my pc together for me and got me a bunch of good deals suggested I wait for the new cards because they would bring prices down. I was skeptical hearing all the Nvidia negativity so I had low expectation and personally predited what we have now with Nvidia disappointing and the graphics card prices going up because of it. I didnt plan on all the other old high end cards selling out (because the new ones suck) so all of my fallback options are sold out and way up in price in the secondhand market. I would have not finished my pc for however long I had to wait this out had I not lucked out and got a 3080ti for $340 seconhand like two weeks ago. I was preparing to not buy a GPU ever and now that I have one I still wont buy another one no matter how dated it gets if they keep trying to rip us off like they have been. So I feel you. I didnt get to see Nvidia fall off because I didnt know they existed until last October so tjey were always bad. I dont have any emotional attachment or fond memories of them, but I do with consoles so I understand the feeling o f being loyal and then the compay betraying you and not wanting to deal with them under any circumstance.

comments.text:
@Bloomingtide It really depends on the CPU you have it with. I have 750W PSU and got it 2 years ago along buying my XTX for ~1050 from AMD's store, but I noticed my Dark Power Pro 550W (with 30 years of 24/7 specced operation time btw) could have handled the load with the 7800X3D I'm having it with. This reference GPU has 350W limit, but I undervolted it to a bit over 320W load since that allows me to have more silent on-load fan speeds, and the CPU eats like 35-50W on games at best with good undervolt too. So from the wall I might take a bit over 400W at the worst times.

My older GTX 980TI at 1500Mhz OC pulled over 400W from the wall already with the 550W PSU, and I used the PSU for 10 years, so it had 20 more years left in it on average. This GPU uses way less power than that old one. So in my case I just upgraded for "piece of mind", not for real benefit. :P

@lifemocker85 You saying that nobody needs to buy any single component for more than $500 is a subjective opinion. There are NO facts involved in that. That is simply how you feel and it applies only to yourself and other people that agree with you, but you are disconnected with reality in that opinion, especially if you're trying to say it's not opinion at all. That being said, I agree that prices are out of control and NVIDIA is certainly trying to screw customers. However, instead of going after NVIDIA's actual pricing on the 5070 Ti, 5080 and 5090... you chose to go after a company that's attempting to offer a reasonable price on their product, given the current economy.

Would it be nice to go back to the days of $400 mid tier GPUs? Absolutely... however, the current economy and a consumeristic society has ruined any hope of that. This is the reality, and a gaming GPU is a want unless you're making money with it, regardless of the price. You don't get to dictate how people spend their money or what their wants are. Besides, for people using their GPU to do actual work... there can be massive benefits in spending more than $500.

comments.text:
For extra context, AMD claim they're overall -2% against the 5070 TI performance.

With an RRP that is $150 lower than the 5070 TI.

They also claimed 46% perf (Edit: I've been reliably informed its 37% for pure raster, 46% for RT) increase over the 7900 GRE in raw raster (no frame gen).

This bit I'm having a harder time proving as 37% uplift  would put it in 5080 territory based on Steve of Gamers Nexus' graph.

Assuming AMD's more pessimistic claim of -2% from the 5070 TI is true, this would put them around 4080 Super performance, which is honestly impressive at $600... Assuming we can find GPUs at that price.

Worth noting AMD aren't making a reference card, only 3rd party cards, so I'd assume +$50-$100 over RRP for typical light OC air cooled version.

On paper it should have been better than the 3060 for my uses. That may still be true, but when I use my pc to watch any streamed movies or shows, the black is blocky and pixilated. This doesn't happen while gaming it's only TV, and it's every platform. I've tried running HDMI from my laptop (intel iris xe) to my monitor, and it looks great so it's not the monitor. I've also tried every solution I can find in 2 years of troubleshooting. I have arrived at the conclusion that price per performance based on paper specs may not tell the whole story. I will not be buying an AMD when I do my new build for many more reasons than this experience.

comments.text:
@Finkaisar You're arguing points I never made and you have no facts. You can't compare NVIDIAs launch to AMDs launch because NVIDIA intentionally shorted supply to focus on producing higher profit margins. It was a paper launch. In the case of AMD, retailers have had cards since January and AMD has had over a month to produce even more cards. They also do not have the same market to sell AI models to like NVIDIA does, which means they are a bit more focused on the gaming market.

I'm not saying that AMD will have so many cards at launch that the bots and scalpers don't buy them all up. That's the sad reality of GPU launches these days. However, it's not likely it will be a paper launch like NVIDIA's and it's far more likely that AMD will be focusing on producing more cards to eventually saturate the market where NVIDIA has had over a month and cards are barely trickling out, not because NVIDIA can't make enough, but because they won't. So, you may never see a huge supply of NVIDIA 50 series cards and you may never see the 7050 Ti anywhere near $750 from this point on.
comments.author: @TheGameBench

comments.text:
@Finkaisar Keep in mind AMD cards still use GDDR6 due to having no real benefit on going GDDR7, since they probably have the same kind of L3 cache trickery or so minimizing the bandwidth requirements, just like RDNA3 has and their X3D CPU's have. So this already saves on production costs not going for the latest. 

Also they're not trying to shove the cards on a tight square block of a board, so still going with 8-pin power design is probably cheaper. All the small stuff adds up in the design, so it might be way easier to manufacture in larger quantities for the MSRP price with some profit even.

comments.text:
@Techington The total P&L has increase massively.  Every single line item has increased significantly over the time period you have described.  R&D in both scope and line item cost has increased, base price and production of materials has increased, shipping has increased, software licensing has increased, not to mention other IT costs such as cloud usage have massively increased bottom lines.  

Keep in mind also that both companies have a fiduciary obligation to increase stock valuation. Since the Datacenter is orders of magnitude more profitable, for the consumer gaming space to even make sense anymore, prices have to go up.   This is especially true when you only have one Architecture like Nvidia currently does and what AMD is going back too.  You only get so many wafers allocated based on your order, so it makes little sense to sell those wafers to a channel that is going to pay 1/15th the price per chip.

comments.text:
@divertiti Emphasizing what Ive said in a few places already:

The 9070XT has the same die size as the 7800XT.

It shares the same 256-bit bus.

It shares the same 16GB GDDR6 VRAM. Its not newer. Its not faster. There isnt any more of it.

The 7800XT launched with all that for $500 two years ago

Now lets back up another step and remember the 7800XT was really the 7700XT misbranded, as its N32 chip was the successor to the 6700XTs N22 chip. That also was the same die size. And the 6700XT launched at $480. Noticing a trend? I dont know where AMDs head is right now, but we can definitely confirm what they were initially thinking. Its exactly the $400-600 range all the early leaks suggested beginning over a year ago.

Yeahthats right. The 8700Xer9070XT die size is the same as the 6700XT. And it has the same VRAM as the 7800XT and 7900GRE. Its not one iota larger or faster. Two years later.
I meanlets be clear this also seriously underscores how abusive Nvidia is and how gullible their buyers arebecause this thing is going to be knocking on 5080 performance (that btw also hasthe same die size)!

But theres ZERO reason AMD cant release the 9070XT and 9070 cards in the general price range of where the 7800XT, 7900GRE, and 6700XT did. We all know AMD has execs and shareholders expecting to leverage their sense of entitlement over this launch by demanding more money per card (they contributed nothing toward designing) while having done nothing but undermine Radeons mindshare the last half-dozen years with horrible pricing structures.

Personally Im very much looking forward to these cards. But if the goal is marketshare most buyers just arent as open-minded as the 10-20% who are educated enough to objectively weigh Nvidia vs AMD and then actually buy AMD when it makes sense. AMD has to price as competitively as they can afford and they have plenty of ability to.
